dialogues.text: David, nobody's happy in a Poodle skirt and a sweater set. (pause ...)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You like all this don't you? David recoils slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, you don't think it's just like dorky or funny or something ... you really like it. (shudders)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh God! I am just so personally horrified right now ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just don't think we have the right to ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David, let me tell you something. These people don't want to be geeks. They want to be "attractive." They've got a lot of potential, they just don't know any better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't have that kind of potential.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um--hello? You want to like take a look? Jennifer motions behind her to a boy and girt who are loc in an intimate conversation. The girl wears bobby socks a the boy wears a letterman's sweater, but the conversation sexually charged. They speak to one another in a close whisper--their faces inches apart. All at once the girt g shy and glances away. She blows a big bubble with her gum but the BUBBLE IS BRIGHT PINK IN AN OTHERWISE GRAY FRAME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. What kind of gum is that? CLOSE. DAVID AND JENNIFER. He looks over in shock as she sucks the BRIGHTLY COLORED BUBBLE GUM back into her mouth. Jennifer flicks her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta go. I'm meeting Biff at the flagpole. EXT. LOVER'S LANE. NIGHT. It is the exact same shot as before: The CAMERA STARTS IT LONG SLOW TRACK behind the vehicles, except this time ALL THEM ARE ROCKING. Various limbs and articles of clothing out the open windows. MOANS of pleasure waft out over Lov Lane as the pond glistens in the distance ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a typical '50s family practice right out of Norman Rockwell. There is a jar of tongue depressors on the coun and a jar of lollipops beside them. Lisa Anne (Mary Sue's best friend) is being examined by Dr. Henderson. Her moth sits at her side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me see it again. Lisa Anne opens her mouth and sticks out a BRIGHT RED TON Everything else in the frame is Black and White, but her tongue literally gleams with color.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (examining it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well ... I don't think it's anything to worry about ... It'll probably just clear up by itself. (to Lisa Anne)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut down on greasy foods and chocolate. No french fries, that kind of thing. (aside/ to the Mother)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just a "teenage" thing. EXT. LOVER'S LANE. NIGHT. It is really rocking now. More cars are lined up along th edge of the lake as the REAL (AND NASTY) VERSION OF TOOTY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... Got a gal--her name is Sue. She knows just what to do ..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Pleasantville Lions lose a game late in the second ha The scoreboard reads 84 to 16 ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David examines the back of the TV set ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large group of customers is huddled in a circle, starin an item on the display floor, like it is the monolith in "2001". They seem both confused and absolutely mesmerized the CAMERA PUSHES IN TO REVEAL: a double bed ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David sits on the floor with a weird look of resignation Brillcream commercial plays in front of him ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "... A wop bop a loo bop--a wop bam boom!" SODA SHOP. NIGHT. ON DAVID. He heads toward work with his apron and his paper hat, bu he's clearly disconcerted. David stops and stares at A BR RED HOT ROD parked at the front door of the restaurant. H shakes his head. SODA SHOP. The place has been transformed. What was cheery and benig couple of days before, has gotten a little bit dangerous. letterman sweaters have been replaced by leather jackets. Pat Boone and Johnny Mathis have given way to real Rock a Roll. There is a James Dean/Marlon Brando edge in the air Somebody has played the flip side. ANGLE. DAVID. He enters the soda shop adjusting his paper hat. A young couple makes out passionately in the doorway--all tongues hands. When they break David sees that the girl's cheeks FLUSHED WITH RED. He stares at her for a beat as they ret to normal. David shakes his head. FOLLOWING HIM. He crosses to the counter and grabs his pencil and little of paper. Various things have already GONE TO COLOR AROUN THE ROOM: The JUKE BOX ... The COKE SIGN .. THE NAUGAHIDE STOOLS ... David crosses to one of the booths where his sister's arm is draped over Biff's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'll it be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still chipper as ever)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee whizz, Bud. Guess I'll just have the usual. Cheeseburger and a cherry coke. Bud has already written it down. He glances over at his sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too. Sounds swell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? It seems so fattening. Before she can answer he smiles to himself and crosses be the counter. Bud posts the order and turns to Mr. Johnson

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two cheeseburgers, two cherry cokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (staring straight ahead)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There aren't any cheeseburgers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. I thought we talked about this, I thought we said ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh--what's the point, Bud? CLOSER. Mr. Johnson. looks up at him with a weird kind of emptine in his eyes. David grabs his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mere. He pulls him along the counter toward a little office storeroom in the back. He yanks him inside and shuts the door. INT. STOREROOM. It is just as cheery as the rest of the place. There is a small table with a telephone on it. A Texaco calendar sho happy family motoring in their Rambler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you say? Mr. Johnson glances down with a little shame and confusio

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well ... I'm not sure I see the point anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about! You make hamburgers! That is the point!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I know ... I know I do ... (he pauses, then looks up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's always the same, you know? Grill the bun, flip the meat, melt the cheese ... It never changes. It never gets any better or worse ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just listen to me ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not hearing him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Like the other night, when I closed up by myself. That was different ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget about that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh ... Okay. (beat/ lower)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... But I really liked it. Bud takes a deep breath. He stares at Mr. Johnson, then t to speak softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, you can't always like what you do. Sometimes you just do it because it's your job. And even if you don't like it, you just gotta do it anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they can have their hamburgers! This sounds stupid even to David. He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like a secret)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I really like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christmastime. David rolls his eyes. Mr. Johnson leans closer, speaking furtively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See every year on Dec 3, I get to paint the Christmas decorations in the window. And every year, I get to paint a different thing ... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One year it's the North Pole. The next I do Santa's workshop. Here I'll show you. He pulls a photo album from the back of the desk and open it for David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow ... That's pretty good ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. (continuing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this morning I was thinking about it and I realized that I looked forward to it all year. And then I thought "Gee. That seems awfully silly. That seems like an awfully long time to be waiting for just one moment, don't you think?" David looks at him speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you should try not to think about this anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Okay. I'll try that then.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BARBERSHOP. DAY
dialogues.text: The Barber Pole spins in three shades of gray. Several me are gathered around the two chairs in the front of Gus' s Besides being the barbershop, it is the bastion of all ma life in Pleasantville. Bud and Mary Sue's "father" (Georg sits in one of the chairs. "Big Bob" McGee, owner of the drugstore, supermarket and Chevy dealership sits in the other. He has a crew cut that's getting shorter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have they ever lost before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Basketball? No they sure haven't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just feels "wrong", that's all. There are several murmurs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe that's where they get that saying, "can't win 'em all."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. That's a good point, Ralph. They do have that saying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they do win 'em all, Gus. They've always won 'em all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yeah. That's true too. More murmurs, Everyone looks straight ahead trying to fig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The women's bridge club has assembled in the Parker kitch like it does every Wednesday afternoon. Four women are se around the kitchen table with a nice bowl of bridge mix between them. Betty is sifting next to Marge Jenkins, the woman who accompanied her daughter to the doctor's office

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dealing the cards)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... He said it would clear up on its own if she just stayed away from fried foods and sweets ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that makes sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Except it's spread to her lips now too. Oh, I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a THIRD WOMAN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you say it's just "red?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well--like red, only ... "redder."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunh. I know what you mean. That's like the front of Bill Johnson's shop. I was going by it the other day and it looked green only "greener." SHOT. BETTY. She looks up quickly--then grabs some bridge mix.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lowering her voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you seen him lately? The man doesn't look like himself. I was getting my sewing machine fixed across the street and he was sitting in the window of his shop just staring. Wasn't looking at anything in particular--just staring off into space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is strange. Betty reaches out and grabs her cards. She fans them out front of her, when her eyes go wide. HER POV. BRIDGE HAND. They are ALL HEARTS and all BRIGHT RED. It looks like a fistfful of valentines. CLOSE UP. BETTY. She puts the cards down quickly and takes a sudden breath Betty keeps them like that for a moment or two, before lifting them up and taking another look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty, it's your bid. She swallows trying to keep her composure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh ... Seven hearts. They murmur at the strength of the hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SOUND of the television plays OS while a warm light b in the window. INT. KITCHEN. Jennifer and Betty stand at the sink finishing the dishes Betty washes while Jennifer dries and it's clear who's mo used to this. Jennifer examines a chipped nail as she pla a dish in the drying rack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Sue?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Betty hesitates. Rinses out a pot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ask you a question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. She pauses for a long moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What goes on up at Lover's Lane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning toward her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you hear all these things lately. You know--kids spending so much time up there ... (she looks over)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it holding hands? That kind of thing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah ... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That--and ... She stops herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I want to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glances toward the living room/ lowers her voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Sex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. Betty nods from the import of the tone but not the meanin beat goes by ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's sex? Jennifer looks over at her stunned, but Betty just looks her with a blank, curious expression. Jennifer hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sure you want to know this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. She crosses to the kitchen door and closes it. The sounds the TV in the living room disappear. Jennifer crosses bac the kitchen counter and turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see Mom ... (softer and with understanding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When two people like each other very much ... Betty looks at her and nods ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TV keeps flickering in the window. INT. KITCHEN. LATER ... The CAMERA PANS across the kitchen table where there is a full quart of milk and some uneaten co6kies. It finally c to rest on Jennifer who is staring across the kitchen tab with a concerned look on her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay? REVERSE ANGLE. BETTY. She nods--shaken but "fine." Betty stares long and hard a the plate of chocolate chip cookies. She's far away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes ... (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just that ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well ... (looking up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Your father would never do anything like that. SHOT. JENNIFER. She bites her lip weighing her next sentence ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning forward)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Hmm ... (whisper/ woman to woman)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Mom ... there's ways to "enjoy" yourself without Dad. ANGLE. BETTY. She looks across the table, perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George crosses from the dresser to the TWO TWIN BEDS in t middle of the room. He wears long sleeve pajamas that are buttoned up to the neck. George puts his glass of warm mi on the nightstand and climbs in his own single bed. It is barely wide enough for his body and takes some maneuverin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweetie? You coming to bed? There is no answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty? INT. BATHROOM. She stands in her bathrobe staring down at the tub. Her dressing gown is buttoned to the neck as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah ... I'm just going to take a bath first. CLOSER. BETTY. She swallows once as she stares down at the tub--then rea for the spigot and turns on the water. Betty's heart beat little faster as she HEARS the WATER THUNDERING DOWN. CLOSER STILL ... Betty reaches up and unties the little silk ribbon at the of her robe. She slips it off, and lets it drop to the fl standing naked in the middle of the bathroom. Betty glanc toward the mirror and then quickly glances away. She take deep breath and steps into the tub. EVEN TIGHTER. ON HER FACE ... Betty slides down into the warm water, breathing in the steam, and closing her eyes for a moment. She lingers lik that for a second or two, before settling a little lower the tub. Betty opens her eyes, but they only half open. T is the slight trace of a smile. EXTREME CLOSE UP BETTY'S FACE. Her eyes close again as she bites her lower lip gently. T water continues to THUNDER DOWN as she arches her back. Betty's breathing seems to quicken as she opens her eyes over again: HER POV. BATHROOM ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares in amazment. Beads of sweat form on Betty's forehead as the world goes to TECHNICOLOR. The THUNDERING WATER POUNDS IN THE BACKGROUND, but beneath can be heard beginnings of a faint, low, MOAN. Her eyes dart around th room. Her breathing quickens: Faster ... Harder ... More intense ... THEN SUDDENLY ... EXT. ELM STREET. NIGHT. The HUGE ELM TREE across the street suddenly BURSTS INTO FLAMES. Fire shoots straight up into the sky as billowing clouds of black smoke fill the air. BRIGHT ORANGE FLAMES LIGHT UP THE NIGHT. INT. PARKER LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. David is staring at the television set when he notices a weird orange glow. He glances behind him, out the living window ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God! EXT. ELM STREET. NIGHT. David comes racing out of the front door and down the wal small CROWD has gathered in front of the fire. (They don' seem frightened--just sort of amazed.) The street is stil BLACK AND WHITE but it is now bathed in a weird ORANGE LI The flames leap higher and higher ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ ... FOLLOWING DAVID. He takes off down the block, as fast as he can run. The c continues to stare as David turns the corner at Main Street ... EXT. FIRE STATION. He races in the front of the building SCREAMING at the to his lungs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no sign of life on the ground floor. David races the stairs toward the bunk room on the second story. INT. BUNKROOM. All the firemen are sitting around playing Gin Rummy when David rushes in the front door. They can hear his voice f down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (entering)

dialogues.speaker: FIRE ... FIRE ...
dialogues.text: They still don't move. All the firemen just look at him f their bunks with a perplexed expression.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: CAT
dialogues.text: All at once they spring to their feet grabbing their helm and their yellow slickers. They race to the landing just outside the bunkroom and leap onto the pole ... EXT. MAIN STREET. NIGHT. The FIRE HAS SPREAD TO AN ADJOINING TREE as the FIRE ENGI comes SCREAMING toward the house from the top of the bloc David sits in the front of the truck next to the Fire Chi who drives the vehicle at break neck speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right here! The Fire ENGINE screeches to a halt. The Fire Chief looks around ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is it? David shoots him a look then glances at the inferno. He shakes his head and leaps from the truck. FOLLOWING DAVID. He races around to the back where the other firemen are standing just as confused. David grabs one of the hoses a begins to pull it from the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here! Grab this nozzle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But where's the ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just grab it! He strips out about fifteen feet of hose, then grabs the fireman and pulls him toward the curb. David parts the cr and positions the man right in front of the flames.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay! Now point this right at the flames--like this. The Fireman nods and does as he is told. David opens the valve sending out a huge FLUME OF WATER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa! (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that's what these do. A huge smile breaks out across the fireman's face--like a who has suddenly found his purpose in life. He beams from to ear dousing the flames, while David runs to get anothe hose ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fading in)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... In honor and in recognition of your heroism ...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TOWN HALL. DAY
dialogues.text: David stands at a podium receiving a commendation from "B Bob McGee (the man from the barbershop). He holds a large plaque up for public display, while "David's" whole famil beams in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... And with great appreciation from the citizens of Pleasantville ... WIDER. A huge crowd is gathered on the town hall steps. There ar lots of balloons and bunting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am pleased to present You with this special commendation, from the Pleasantville Chamber of Commerce! He hands the plaque to David as the entire town bursts in APPLAUSE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David walks away from the center of town looking down at plaque. He takes his sleeve and starts to rub off a smudg when a young woman comes up beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Bud ... WIDER. She is MARGARET ANNE HENDERSON, the prettiest girl in sch and one of the most popular. Margaret wears a frilly polk dot dress, that only accentuates a bombshell '50s figure. Nonetheless, she seems the image of girly innocence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was sure swell ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Thanks, Margaret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I baked you my oatmeal cookies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (vaguely remembering an episode)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no ... You baked those for Whitey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I baked them for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You baked them for Whitey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (low and gutteral)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I baked them for you. All at once, Margaret grabs his arm and presses herself u against him. Her breasts shove up against his chest. Her mouth is inches away from his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um ... thanks. David can smell the weird combination of hot moist breath freshly baked cookies. He stares into her eyes for a mome unable to speak. Margaret flashes him a not-so Pleasantvi smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See ya. She turns and heads around the comer, while David just watches her dumbstruck.

dialogues.speaker: SODA SHOP. DUSK.
dialogues.text: David heads toward work with his apron and little paper h The BUDDY HOLLY music has given way to "hip" '50s JAZZ. D BRUBECK drifts out of the soda shop as David pauses for a moment, takes a bite of his oatmeal cookie, and heads ins SODA SHOP. The place has "morphed" even more. If it was a teenage hangout before, it has become almost a Bohemian coffee ho now. Brubeck's "TAKE FIVE" plays in the background while several patrons talk "intensely" in their booths. DOORWAY. David walks into the building and pauses. Next to him, on the boys from the basketball team plays along with the ja on a BONGO DRUM. There are several COFFEE cups on the tab Jennifer gets up quickly and comes over to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had nothing to do with that fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not directly anyhow ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine. David glances at the booth beside them and realizes that bongos have stopped playing. All the kids are staring up him, with a weird expression of awe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still under her breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um ... They like wanna ask you a question ... I didn't know how to handle it. So ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. He crosses to the booth where Biff and two others look up him. It's like Elvis has entered the building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you doin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swell ... They keep on staring. Several glances are exchanged back forth like they're sharing a secret. Finally ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you know about the fire?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you know how to put it out and all? David hesitates, weighing his words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well--where I used to live ... That's just what firemen did. This sends a MURMUR through the shop. The boy leans forwa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And where's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (carefully)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um ... Outside of Pleasantville. This sends a much LOUDER MURMUR rifling through the kids. It's like electricity. They glance excited at one another hush descends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's outside of Pleasantville?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look it doesn't matter. It's not important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? David stops and looks out at the kids who are hanging on every word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's really not important.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's outside of Pleasantville? REVERSE ANGLE. INCLUDING DOORWAY. Margaret Henderson (the girl with the cookies) stands in doorway staring at David. She hangs on his words with the same excitement as the others, it just means so much more

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hungry for knowledge)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon. Tell us ... She stares right in his eyes. She's ten feet away but mig as well be touching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well ... There are some places where the road doesn't go in a circle. There are some places where it keeps on going. There's an excited giggle. They lean forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (an exotic concept)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keeps going ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well--it all just keeps going. Roads ... rivers ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like the "Mighty Mississippi".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... What? He moves forward extending a book. The cover reads: "THE ADVENTURES OF HUCKELBERRY FINN." David opens the first pa There is printing inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quoting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "It was big 'n brown 'n kept goin' an' goin' as far you could see."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to Jennifer)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought the books were blank?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were. He looks over at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay look, this like--wasn't my fault. They asked me what it was about and I like didn't remember 'cause we had it back in tenth grade, But I told them what I DID remember, and the next thing I knew the pages had filled in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pages filled in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But like only up to the part about the raft, because I didn't read any farther. CLOSER. David flips through the book and sure enough only the fir chapter has print. The pages are blank after that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know how it ends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hesitating)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, yeah ... I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breathless)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how does it end? She has moved closer and is gazing at him from a couple o feet away. It's silent in the soda shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well--see ... they're both running away--Huck and the slave ... And ... They go up the river ... But--in trying to get free they sort of see that they're free already. David looks immediately down to the blank pages of the bo that aren't blank anymore. Rows and rows of FRESH NEW TYP materialize in front of him. He turns to the back of the book, that is complete with a COLOR illustration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know this one? He shoves another book in front of David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunh? (looks down at the book)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah ... Well this is great. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See--Holden Caulfield is like this really lonely kid... EXT. PLEASANTVILLE PUBLIC LIBRARY. DAY. The CAMERA PANS down from the "PUBLIC LIBRARY' sign to fi the front door. A long line of kids waiting to check out their books stretches onto the sidewalk ... EXTREME WIDE SHOT. LIBRARY. FROM ACROSS THE STREET. Several men from the barbershop lean against the wall nex the spinning barber pole. They watch the spectacle for a moment or two, as teenager after teenager exits with an armful of books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know Phil. It's pretty strange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll say it's strange. Gettin' stranger. Big Bob McGee nods and rubs his hands over his fresh hair

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean goin' up to that lake all the time is one thing, but now they're going to a library! I mean what's next?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oughtta be havin' an ice cream soda. That's where they oughtta be. WIDER STILL. From the shadows of the Town Hall, up the block, David watches the stream of kids emerge with their books. They cradle them in their hands like a piece of newfound treasure ... INT. PARKER LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. George sits on the edge of his Barka Lounger, across the coffee table from "Big" Bob McGee. Even sitting down the is a looming presence. Besides owning the market, auto dealership, hardware store, and gas station, he also owns insurance agency where George works. George sweats into h collar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want some bridge mix?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no thanks ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty's making some pineapple kabobs ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine--but thank you. George nods as Bob takes a belt of his Martini and leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, you're probably wondering why I asked if I could come over today ... George shrugs--then nods--then shrugs ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure you've noticed the same things we all have--certain "changes" going on in the town. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I mean by "changes"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Changes."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Changes." (takes a belt of martini)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's not just the fire or big stuff like that. It's little things. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you hear about Bill Miller?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wife wants him to get one of those new beds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of those ... big beds? Bob nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my gosh. What's he gonna to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really don't know. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ben Miller's son just quit his job as a boxboy at the market.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Said he didn't want to do it anymore. Just took off his apron in the middle of an order. Mrs. Thompson had her groceries spread all over the counter ... Took 'em four hours to sort the whole thing out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy cow. Bob takes a belt of his drink ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, everyone likes you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh well ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. They do. And it isn't just 'cause you're a great bowler ... They respect you ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heartfelt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's important for them to see someone they respect, stand up for what's right. If you love a place, you can't sit around and watch this kind of thing happen to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (big patriarchal smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's why I want you to be on the Pleasantville Chamber of Commerce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stunned/ moved)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my Gosh. I hardly know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you start by saying "yes," and then getting me one of those swell pineapple kabobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh sure ... You bet. (calling out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty ... There is no answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (louder this time)

dialogues.speaker: BETTY ...
dialogues.text: Still no answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George turns around to see David, standing on the landing listening to the entire conversation. Their eyes lock for moment ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get her. He moves quickly to the kitchen shutting the door behind INT. KITCHEN. David gets a couple of steps in and stops. He looks acros the room to see: REVERSE ANGLE. Betty standing at the kitchen sink, just staring out the window. Her back is to him. She grips the formica kitchen counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (approaching slowly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay? She doesn't answer. David moves up to her and rests a han her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you alright? Betty turns around to face him. HER FACE HAS TURNED

dialogues.speaker: COMPLETELY TO COLOR. THE EYES ARE GREEN. THE LIPS ARE RED
dialogues.text: SHE HAS A NATURAL BLUSH IN HER CHEEKS. In fact the whole thing looks like a beautiful color portrait except for th tear stains on either side of her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fighting tears)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I going to do? David moves closer and looks at her. Her lip is quivering

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. It's alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trembling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't go out there. How can I go out there? She looks right up at David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quieter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me ... DIFFERENT ANGLE. He stares at her for a second. Big green eyes full of fea and confusion. David pushes a reassuring smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you got any make up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In my handbag. He crosses to the counter and grabs her purse. David sits Betty on a kitchen chair and fishes inside the handbag fo her compact. He finds it along with a wadded up Kleenex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay--first we'll dry you out a little. He dabs at the tears, while she smiles at him in gratitud Then David opens the compact and takes out the large GRAY powder puff. CLOSER. It is a truly amazing sight. As David smears on the makeu she returns gradually to BLACK AND WHITE. The skin tones disappear. The flush of her cheeks goes. David takes out DARK GRAY lipstick, obliterating the bright red of her li REVERSE ANGLE. OVER BETTY'S SHOULDER. He works on her for a second or two, then takes a step ba All at once, David seems to wince: REVERSE ANGLE. HIS POV. BETTY'S FACE. The life is gone from her face. In an instant Betty has g from three dimensions to two. She stands in front of him, fictional version of herself all over again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off his reaction)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? David shakes his head and forces a smile. He hands her th compact so she can examine herself. Betty holds it up to face, turning her head first right, then left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does it look okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks just like it did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they won't be able to tell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (even quieter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No ... They won't be able to tell. Betty takes a deep breath and fluffs her hair. She grabs plate of Pineapple kabobs and heads for the door. Just be she goes in, she pauses, then plasters on a big wide "stewardess" smile ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? He wants to say something, but doesn't. David shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine. She smiles again and balances the tray in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sadly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. He watches as she opens the door, and marches in the room extending the little tray of hors d'oeuvres in front of her ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Johnson is all alone in the shop, setting up the napk dispensers. He whistles BRUBECK'S "TAKE FIVE" when the sc door slams behind him. Mr. Johnson looks up with a start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (entering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you a little early?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I brought you something ... From the library. CLOSER. FOLLOWING DAVID. He has a large book tucked under his arm that is easily t feet long. Mr. Johnson looks at him a little intrigued as David crosses to the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an art book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my Gosh, Bud ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open it. Mr. Johnson reaches out and opens the cover. After a beat his eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just thought since you liked painting it might help to ... Mr. Johnson gasps. It's quiet, and subtle, but it's still gasp. David looks over at him but he's lost in the pages. HIS POV. (INSERT) ART BOOK ... Massacio's "Expulsion of Adam and Eve' leaps off the page vibrant, tortured color. The beauty of the garden is offs by their agony and their shame. HE TURNS THE PAGE ... Titian's "Venus to Utano". Soft, fleshy, in a rich golden light. She is utterly real and entirely nude. The folds o her flesh almost seem to glow ... Rembrandt's "Self Portrait." Dark reds, umbers, blacks an browns. He looks back at Mr. Johnson with pain and wisdom There's a brilliant light on his hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmmgh ... Faintly, almost imperceptibly, the SOUND of a rich ARIA begins to UNDERSCORE THE IMAGES. It's so faint you can't sure you even hear it at all ... like you're hearing it w your eyes. He TURNS THE PAGES faster. Breugal's "Harvesters" ... Tum "Steam Train" ... Monet's "Cathedralo" ... Cezanne's "Oranges" ... Mr. Johnson shuts the book. WIDER. SODA SHOP. They sit like that for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful, Bud ... He looks up at David, troubled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll never be able to do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, well--you're just starting out. I mean, you can't do it ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that's not it. Mr. Johnson shuts the book gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where am I going to see colors like that? ANGLE. DAVID. What can he say. David looks over at Mr. Johnson who just smiles and shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be awfully lucky to see colors like that. I bet they don't even know how lucky they are. CLOSE UP. DAVID. He just stares for a second. EXT. MAIN STREET. LONG SHOT. DAY. Margaret walks up the center of Main Street toward the CA with her books pressed against her chest. She passes the drugstore, then the hardware store ... Far off in the distance, a young man comes racing out of the soda shop, pulling off his little paper hat as he goes. He comes run up behind her as fast as he can. CLOSER. He takes a deep breath and tries to quiet the panting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning/ lighting up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh ... Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I probably shouldn't be asking you this--not knowing you that well and all ... Margaret stops in the street and turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just that my folks are gonna stay home and they said I could use their car. (moment of truth/ abandoning his speech)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... You want to go out with me tonight? He wants to turn away but doesn't. David forces himself t stare at her and all of a sudden she beams. It's the whit pearliest smile in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breathless)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure ... Where would we go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (swallows)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Lover's Lane?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David comes flying around the corner in complete jubilati He vaults over a parking meter, swings around a lampost a leaps off the bumper of a parked car. David hi-fives into air at no one in particular and sails over Mr. Simpson's hedge almost decking him in the process.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry ... FOLLOWING DAVID. He races across the street bobbing and weaving like an Al American fullback. David bounds up his front steps two at time flinging open the door. INT. PARKER HOUSE. FOYER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Oh when the Saints ... Go Marching in ..." He lets the door slam behind him as he takes off his apro and tosses it on the coat rack. David starts up the stair when he HEARS a MAN'S VOICE coming from the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud ... He pauses a second and glances back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David ... He peers into the living room. David goes a little grayer HIS POV. TELEVISION. Dick Van Dyke is looking back at him from the middle of t TV screen. He seems to have a bit of a stubble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wary)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stage whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well c'mere, young fella. INT. LIVING ROOM. David crosses slowly over to the TV set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (big smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I've been thinkin' ... I might have been a little "hasty" the other day when you asked to come home--just took me by such surprise, ya know--ha ha ... He gives a goony laugh. David just looks at him ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So even though I can't make any promises, well--I figured if you asked me real nice--I might just be willing to talk about it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Talk about it. Right now, I mean. I got to ... um ... The look turns suddenly dark and ominous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud--I thought you wanted to come home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh ... I do. Yeah. It's just that I told my "dad" I'd clean out the rain gutters and Mr. Johnson wanted me to ... to change the tape in the register ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting testy)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be honest with you Bud. I'm getting sorta concerned about what I'm seeing in some of these re-runs ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Re-runs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like when Margaret Henderson makes her cookies for Whitey. (losing it a little)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Those aren't your cookies Bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I know they're not. But I mean-- they're just "cookies" after all ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well they're not just cookies. I mean, they're great cookies ... Look, I'd love to get into this whole thing but I'm really running late. Why don't we hook up tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Terrific. I'll talk to you then. He swttches off the TV sending Dick Van Dyke to electroni limbo. David stands in the middle of the living room, breathing hard ... INT. JENNIFER'S (MARY SUE'S) ROOM. She sits on the bed staring down at the front cover of a book. (It's an alien experience.) Jennifer is just about open it when she senses something and glances toward the door. REVERSE ANGLE. Bud is standing in the doorway just staring at her. He se to be out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing? He keeps breathing hard in the doorway. David holds the remote in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen ... He takes a couple of steps into the room and then suddenl stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're reading?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glancing at the book)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Can't believe you started such a dorky fad. She holds up the cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: D.H. Lawrence. You ever heard of him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (amazed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seemed kinda sexy. Look. I read 35 pages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still stunned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great. He just stares at her for a second as his mind seems to drift ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well ... I just ... (out of the blue)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ask you a question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember when you told me that Lisa Rosenberg liked me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well--did she really like me or were you just making that up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. She really liked you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't playing a joke? She woulda gone out with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gone out with you. She woulda like rearranged your tonsils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. He looks at her amazed--reliving the missed opportunity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I ask you a question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come I'm still in black and white?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back to earth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I've had like ten times as much sex as these girls and I'm still like this. They have one hour in the back of a car and suddenly they're in technicolor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know. Maybe ... (thinks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... it's not just the sex ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? She stares at him wide-eyed like someone who has just hea their name called. Jennifer's eyes dart around like she's calculating a math problem. After a moment or two, her expression changes: a vague look of recognition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's not just the sex, is it? She glances down at her book. It's a big book. Jennifer t a deep breath and stares at the gray skin of her hand. Af a second or two, she looks back. David looks at her for a beat ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David gets out of his "dad's" convertible, carrying a doz "gray" roses. He takes a deep breath and heads up her fro walk ... INT. CAR. NIGHT. LATER ... David sits behind the wheel of the borrowed car with Marg Henderson by his side. He concentrates hard on the road, holding the wheel at "10 and 2" as he steals a glance to right. HIS POV. MARGARET. It's not quite evening yet, and late afternoon light make her glow. Margaret smiles as she turns her face into the wind that swirls inside the convertible ... SHOT. DAVID. He studies her for a moment or two, then suddenly swerves avoid a parked car on his right ... WIDER. They pass a sign with a happy family on it that reads:

dialogues.speaker: "NOW LEAVING PLEASANTVILLE"
dialogues.text: Main Street turns into a winding country road as they lea the town behind and head off into the woods. They wind through the dense woodland for a moment or two before a second sign appears, much like the first:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure enough, the town emerges in front of them again, completing the 4 dimensional circle. David looks confused

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um ... You gotta turn off Main Street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh ... Right. He looks over at her and smiles. Margaret turns on the ra EXT. CAR. DUSK. SAM COOKE sings for them as David turns from Main Street a smaller unmarked lane. The car starts to rise up a smal hill, with Dogwood trees blooming on either side of the r It continues to climb up the narrow gravel lane toward th crest in the hill. David looks over at Margaret who takes deep breath shutting her eyes. He glances down at the sea between them ... HIS POV. CAR SEAT.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROSES THAT WERE GRAY HAVE SUDDENLY TURNED TO COLOR. T
dialogues.text: sit next to him on the seat: a deep, rich RED ... INT. CAR. David looks up and out the windshield. The same thing see to be happening around them ... Many of the Dogwoods have started to turn PINK. Not all of them, but at least fifty percent of the petals have "bloomed" in some weird false spring. The road twists and turns on its way to the top, they finally reach a crest in the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. THEIR POV. LOVERS LANE. There, sitting in front of them, is a whole world gone Technicolor: THE LAKE IS BLUER THAN BLUE. THE WEEPING WIL IS GREENER THAN GREEN. THE DOGWOOD PETALS (all "turned" n

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over the car radios)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Cupid, draw back your bow ..." SHOT. CAR. Slowly, David rolls the convertible forward. Many of the have left their cars and sit down along the grassy bank b the edge of the water. A few of them have books open. It almost looks "Athenian." INT. CAR. David looks at the whole scene for a moment then suddenly cocks his head to the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that smell? Margaret looks at him and smiles. She leans well out of t convertible, and plucks a Gardenia from a bush that is blooming beside the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't these great? David takes the flower, then puts it up to his nose. He t a long deep breath then all at once, his posture seems to relax. As the fragrance enters his body his eyes drift li some strange narcotic is washing over him. David lowers t flower ... EXT. MAIN STREET. DUSK. Betty is walking down Main Street with a shopping bag on either hand. From a block away, she looks like any other homemaker in Pleasantville. You don't even notice the gra make-up. CLOSER. FOLLOWING BETTY. She nods to Mrs. Filmore in the bakery and smiles at Don the Post Office. Betty is just about to turn on Elm Stree when she glances up, and suddenly stops. HER POV. ACROSS THE STREET. There, in the middle of the block, sits Mr. Johnson's sod shop. The whole scene is still black and white, except fo the large CUBIST PAINTING THAT FILLS MR. JOHNSON'S WINDOW is rendered in bright PINKS, YELLOWS AND ORANGES, and loo like a Braque or a Picasso except for the unusual subject matter. Upon closer examination you see that all the sphe and cones add up to an avante garde snow scene, with a Cu Santa hovering over the roof tops. SHOT. BETTY. She stares at it, mesmerized for a moment, then starts to wander across the street. It's late afternoon and the business district is empty. Betty crosses in the middle o the block, staring straight ahead. INT. SODA SHOP. The door opens and she sticks her head inside. Most of th place is dark except for one streak of sunlight shining through the window near the back of the store. Betty glan around. The little bell JINGLES as she enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're closed right now ... DIFFERENT ANGLE. He sits in front of a small easel near the back, staring board which doubles as a canvas. Mr. Johnson glances over shoulder and recognizes Betty in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hi ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to leave)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no ... Come on in. REVERSE ANGLE. He gets up from his stool and crosses toward the door, st holding the palette in his hand. Betty stares at the "Cub Christmas" in the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just thought ... It's beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. Their eyes lock for a second. Sort of a clutzy silence. M Johnson motions toward his easel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just trying to do one of these "still lifes." He sighs and looks behind him. Next to the easel is a bow GRAY FRUIT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Having kind of a tough time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it looks nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well ... (shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's what it's s'posed to look like. He leads her over to the table and points down at the art book. It's open to a Cezanne that nearly burns off the pa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my ... CLOSER. They are standing almost on top of each other gazing down the book. Neither one of them moves. Betty almost disappe into the pictures--drawn by a strange new world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. Look at this. He turns to Kandinsky--a massive swirl of color. The imag nearly electric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breathless)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you get this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud brought it to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's my favorite. INSERT. BOOK. He turns the page near the back to one of Picasso's "Weep Women." The woman is rendered in pink and red and green. head is a large sphere, laying "peacefully" on her own shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think? She doesn't answer ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't it great how she's resting like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (faintly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's crying. WIDER. Mr. Johnson looks down at the painting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No she's not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes she is. He looks up at her ... REVERSE ANGLE. A single tear is running down Betty's cheek. She senses i and reaches up to wipe it quickly away, but instead of ju wiping the tear, she takes off a huge swath of GRAY MAKE- A long strip of PINK FLESH is revealed underneath. ANGLE. MR. JOHNSON. He stares up at her in amazement. ANGLE. BETTY. She senses something and glances down at her hand. Her fingertips are covered in GRAY MAKE-UP. Betty turns and b for the door. WIDER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (following her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got to go ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's alright. He stops her near the door and she turns her face toward wall. Mr. Johnson touches her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's alright. Let me see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shame)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No ... He reaches up and gently touches her chin. Mr. Johnson mo around to glimpse the other side of her cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful. CLOSER ... She freezes like that for a moment, then slowly, haltingl turns toward him. THE COLOR of her real flesh is revealed underneath. Betty stands there exposed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... It's beautiful. She swallows, not sure what to do. Betty glances down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You shouldn't cover that up. Mr. Johnson reaches over to the little napkin dispenser o the counter and pulls one out. He leans forward and dabs the tears beneath Betty's eyes. Then slowly, gently, he starts to wipe the makeup off her cheek. CLOSER STILL ... She recoils a bit, tensing up, then just looks at him. Mr Johnson is gazing at her "true color" with wonder and acceptance. She hesitates for an instant, then seems to m a decision. Betty slowly turns her face to the side, expo her flesh all the way down to the neck. Mr. Johnson conti to wipe off the make up in larger and larger strokes as t beautiful pink flesh begins to emerge ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She lies on her bed, reading the same book she was browsi earlier. Jennifer seems strangely engrossed as she flips pages, lying on her stomach, scouring every word. After a moment or two she gets restless and shifts position, lift the book. The cover is plainly visible: "LADY CHATTERLY'S

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She doesn't have enough light so Jennifer rises from the and crosses to "her" desk. She sits in the chair and flat the book in front of her. Jennifer is deep into the plot doesn't even look up as she flicks on the desk lamp. She could almost be studying algebra as she sits upright at t little desk. DIFFERENT ANGLE. She flips the page and peers more intently. Her hair is bothering her so she pulls it back and knots it in a pony tail. After a little while her eyes begin to get more tir and she looks up and blinks a couple of times. Jennifer notices something across the desk. REVERSE ANGLE. A pair of Mary Sue's glasses are neatly folded in front o her. Jennifer reaches out, puts them on her head, glances back down at the print.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunh. She can see much clearer now. Jennifer folds her hands in front of her and doesn't even realize that she has mimick the PHOTOGRAPH OF MARY SUE THAT SITS BESIDE HER IN A SILV FRAME. The face is the same, but that's to be expected. S the pony tail, the glasses, the posture and the studious on her face. Jennifer turns the page engrossed in her nov when there is a loud TAP on the window. She rises from the desk and pulls back the curtain. Jenni slides open the window. EXT. PARKER HOUSE. Biff stands on the front lawn tossing pebbles at the wind

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mary Sue--C'mon ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning out the window)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (jiggling in anticipation)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's six-thirty ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were gonna ... You know ... He jiggles some more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (remembering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? She glances down at her book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With what? INT. JENNIFER'S ROOM. She hesitates for a second then glances back at the desk. own image in the silver frame stares back at her. The hai pulled back in a pony tail. The glasses sit on the front her nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (turning to Biff)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm studying. She thinks about it for a moment, then suddenly smiles. B stands dumbfounded on the sidewalk as Jennifer reaches up quietly closes the window ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Margaret sit on the edge of the grass, looking across the water. Even in the moonlight, the COLORS are vivid. David still clutches the gardenia in his hand, tak a long hit like an Opium addict.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (inhaling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmmgh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do they have those ... Where you come from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah ... I guess. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know? Margaret laughs like that isn't even possible. She shifts the grass hiking her skirt up above the knee. It reveals long tan leg beneath it. David watches as she kicks off h shoes, rubbing her feet through the long cool grass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's it like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out there. She clings onto the words like they could transport her b themselves. David thinks for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. don't know ... It's different. She leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well it's louder ... And scarier I guess ... And ... and a lot more dangerous ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds fantastic. You know some kids came up here the other night to go swimming--took off all their clothes. She giggles. David looks at her in amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do they have an Ocean? I've heard about the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that like?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well it's big. And it's blue ... (as if realizing it for the first time)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... It's really really blue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmm. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy. It's hot up here. Suddenly and without warning Margaret unbuttons her cardi sweater. She slips it off, arching her back like the figurehead of a ship and David just stares at her breasts She wears a light cotton blouse and even in the moonlight forms a translucent silhouette ... She lays the sweater across the grass and leans back on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want some berries?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hunh? She unfolds a handkerchief revealing a handful of berries REDS AND BLUES AND PURPLES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I picked them myself. They grow wild up here. (eating one)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmm. So sweet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at them)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They just grow like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking straight up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. There's a lot of stuff. Currants and strawberries ... Here. I'll show you. She hops up and scampers across the grassy bank, kicking heels behind her. Margaret reaches a tree in the distance reaches toward an upper limb, stretching out her body lik piece of statuary. She picks a piece of fruit and scamper back toward him, hiking up her skirt as she goes ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here. CLOSER. Margaret sticks out her hand, offering him a BRIGHT RED APPLE. It's brilliant and shiny and glistens in the moonlight. ANGLE. DAVID. He hesitates just looking at it. Margaret speaks in a whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on. Try it. HIS POV. She is lying on her stomach now, and behind the outstretc apple he can see an ample view of her cleavage. Margaret smiling at him as the apple shines in the foreground. Dav reaches out and takes it. WIDER. DAVID AND MARGARET. For this instant, they seem alone in the garden. He looks down at it, then glances over at Margaret. David hesitate for a split second then takes a bite of the apple ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George heads home with his briefcase in hand whistling a happy tune. He smiles at Mr. Simpson and swings the attac case as he turns and heads up his front walk. INT. FOYER. George opens the door and sets the briefcase by the stair like he always does. He hangs his hat on the hatrack, his coat on the coatrack, and beams as he hollers his nightly greeting:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey--I'm home. There is no response. He looks a little perplexed but smi as he calls out again:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey--I'm home ... There is more silence. George looks around a little confu when there is a BOOMING CLAP OF THUNDER ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty sits in a comer of the shop, next to the gray bowl fruit. She holds her head to the side, sitting gracefully with her chin in the air. Mr. Johnson sits behind his eas painting her portrait from a few feet away. Betty looks radiant with no trace of the makeup, the warm PINK OF HER FLESH TONES lit softly by a bare forty watt bulb ... CLOSER. She looks over at Mr. Johnson when they hear the BOOMING OF THUNDER. Each of them freezes. There is ANOTHER, LOUDE BOOM ... ANGLE. WINDOW. The "Cubist Snowscene" lights up brightly, illuminated by sudden flash of lightning behind it. Betty leaps up from chair and crosses to the window looking out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frightened)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Betty looks back at Mr. Johnson and suddenly sees the painting. She flinches for a second. Her eyes go wide. REVERSE ANGLE. INCLUDING THE PAINTING. It is Cubist (like the rest of his recent work) but that isn't the shocking part. Even though she sits in front of fully clothed, Mr. Johnson has painted a beautiful, sensu nude. Betty just stares at the canvas, stunned to see her revealed like that. The COLORS are all hot pinks and oran and yellows--like some Fauvist celebration of summertime. There is another even LOUDER PEEL OF THUNDER. WIDER. BETTY AND MR. JOHNSON. She looks over at Mr. Johnson and he glances down. After moment or two he looks back at her, but she doesn't turn run. Betty just stares at him, then without even realizin it, moves slightly closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Margaret are locked in a deep passionate kiss. first they don't separate when they hear the BOOMING CLAP THUNDER. It is only when they hear the SECOND ONE and the RAIN starts to fall, that Margaret pulls back and looks u the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that? ANGLE. DAVID. He is still in an amorous daze and doesn't even feel the increasing rain. It starts to pound harder and Margaret l to him in terror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Real rain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah ... You don't have rain either? She looks at him frightened. David smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. Of course you don't ... He puts his jacket around her and starts to lead her up t grassy slope. A dozen other couples go scurrying up the b looking in terror at the water falling from the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reaching the car)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll just put up the top. He goes fishing around the boot of the car, looking for t catch to release it. David leans into the back seat fishi around as the rain starts to pound harder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What top? He looks back at her. No top either. David smiles, drench in rain and puts his arm around Margaret who is starting shiver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine. Come on. He leads her back to a thicket of bushes where several of kids are clustered together. They look at one another, terrified, as they huddle for shelter beneath the ledge o overhanging rock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's alright. There's nothing to be afraid of. They look a little reassured and Margaret looks up at him positively adoringly. She clings to his shoulder as the s howls a few feet away ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stands at the window looking out at the driving rain. Jennifer still holds the D.H. Lawrence book in her hand. There is a huge flash of lightning and another clap of thunder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cool ... She flops back down on the bed and continues to read ... PARKER LIVING ROOM. George wanders through the empty and darkened house completely perplexed and utterly disoriented. He looks ar for his family, but all he can find are the darkened room and the sound of the driving storm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a little frightened/ a little petulant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, I'm home ... He still can't find her and he crosses into the DINING RO The lights are dark there as well and he looks around confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (baffled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's my dinner? He sniffs a couple of times but there are no familiar coo smells. George flings open the door to the kitchen but th empty as well. KITCHEN. He crosses into the darkness ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's my dinner ... INT. FOYER. George comes reeling out of the kitchen into the foyer. H slams his shin on the coatrack but keeps on going ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (insistent)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's my DINNER ... EXT. HOUSE. It's really blowing now. The rain is coming down in heavy sheets, being swirled and driven by the wind. The front d opens and George wanders out onto the front porch, still dressed in his shirtsleeves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's my DINNER! ON GEORGE. He stumbles down the front walk in a state of complete confusion. The rain pounds against his body and within seconds his shirt is soaked through to the skin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over the storm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tree limb crashes to the ground but he keeps stumbling through the torrent. George reels down Elm Street screami skyward in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS. FOLLOWING GEORGE ...
dialogues.text: He turns on Main Street and goes reeling past the insuran agency where he works. George howls into the wind and he passes the hardware store, the gas station, the bakery .. Finally he pauses outside the barbershop. It's empty as w with the spinning barber pole being buffeted by the rain. George lowers his arms and just stares into the darkened shop. His voice grows quieter bewildered and shivering ..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (plaintively)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's my dinner? He wraps his arms around himself and shivers on the sidew INT. BOWLING ALLEY. NIGHT. The regular occupants of the barber shop spread out acros three lanes. Each wears a Pleasantville bowling shirt, sponsored by one of Big Bob's businesses. The NOISE from the crashing pins is deafening and there aren't any windows so the storm has gone unnoticed ... ANGLE. BIG BOB. He picks up a 7-10 split and claps his hands in delight. starts to cross back to the scorer's table when he looks and suddenly stops. REVERSE ANGLE. HIS POV. George is standing in the doorway to the bowling alley co and shivering. His shirt is soaked through to the skin. H hair is drenched and dripping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened? He doesn't answer. George clutches his body and keeps shivering. WIDER. The men stop bowling and rush to George's side. He blinks couple of times, still soaked to the bone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you alright? (looking at him)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (faintly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Real rain? George nods. Bob rushes to the glass door of the bowling alley and sees the driving storm. A huge fork of lightnin lights up the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God ... He turns back to George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... We had no idea. Burt was rolling a 250 and ... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you alright? George shivers and Bobs leads him over to one of the benc and guides him into the seat ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still shivering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I ... I came home like I always do, And I came in the front door. And I took off my coat. And I put down my briefcase and I said "Honey. I'm home." ANGLE. MEN. They all nod in recognition. ANGLE. GEORGE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Only no one was there. A MURMUR goes through the men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I went into the kitchen and I yelled it again. "Honey--I'm home." But there was no one there either. No wife. No lights. No dinner. They all GASP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I went to the oven--you know-- because I thought maybe she had made me one of those "TV dinners ..." The men nod and lean forward. George shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she hadn't. She was gone. A LOUDER MURMUR moves through the crowd. George lowers hi head and just shakes it from side to side. Big Bob moves and puts a hand on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently/ the patriarch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... It's gonna be fine George. George looks up at him helplessly. Bob pats him reassurin on the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we do Bob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well--we'll be safe for now--thank goodness we're in a bowling alley-- but if George here doesn't get his dinner, any one of us could be next. It could be you Gus, or you Burt, or even you Phil ... They murmur again. Bob gathers a little steam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like a WWII movie)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... That's real rain out there gentlemen. This isn't some little "virus" that's going to "clear up on it's own." There's something happening to our town and I think we can all see where it comes from. They nod in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
