dialogues.text: We're gonna need a town meeting. Phil, how fast can you turn around a leaflet in your print shop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couple of hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus, why don't you get a bunch of kids from the basketball team to help you put them up on lamposts and tree trunks ... Gus nods. Big Bob turns to George and smiles. It's a warm patriarchal smile. He claps a hand on George's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soothingly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the first thing you're gonna do is get a cup of hot cocoa and a nice dry bowling shirt. INT. SODA SHOP. NIGHT. The rain still pounds out the window. Betty and Mr. Johns are huddled in one of the booths watching the deluge thro Mr. Johnson's snow scene in the window. Betty is in soft radiant color now. Almost the whole frame seems to glow pink ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't go out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I really should get home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you can't go out there. There is another fork of lightning and a booming peel of THUNDER. Betty sighs. She's past struggling. Betty shuts eyes for a moment and listens to the rain pounding on the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds nice ... Once you get used to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (listening)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. It does. There is another flash and a loud BOOM. Betty smiles this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like a drum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. (thinks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or like sprinklers in the summer ... Betty smiles. They both listen for a moment and the fear seems to fade a little. The RAIN POUNDS harder on the roo Betty nestles down in the booth, a little closer to Mr. Johnson. They just sit there listening for a moment or tw Betty starts to smile ... EXT. LOVER'S LANE. David huddles with Margaret under the rocky ledge as she nestles against him with her head on his shoulder. INT. JENNIFER'S ROOM. She lies on her bed, still reading the book, the spitting image of Mary Sue. Her hair is up in a bun now. The glass have slipped down her nose. There is another fork of lightning and the LOUDEST THUNDER CLAP of all. Jennifer smiles slightly and pulls Mary Sue's afghan over her shoulders as she fluffs the pillow and turns the page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drops of moisture cling to the petals as it GLEAMS BRILLI RED IN THE MORNING SUN ... AERIAL SHOT. PLEASANTVILLE. The rain is gone now. The town glistens in the sunlight complete with a huge RAINBOW arching across the sky. Literally all the COLORS IN THE RAINBOW shine against the black and white of the town. It looks like a greeting car INT. SODA SHOP. Betty and Mr. Johnson are asleep in the booth, lying in e other's arms. Sunlight streams in through the window, war Mr. Johnson's face which has now turned to color. He open his eyes and looks outside ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (seeing the rainbow)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my Gosh ... EXT. LOVER'S LANE. Birds are chirping. David and Margaret also lie asleep in each other's arms, beneath the shelter of the rocky overh Margaret lifts up and sees the rainbow. She has turned to color as well ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (awed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God ... INT. JENNIFER'S ROOM. She has passed out on her bed with her book on her chest. Jennifer's hair is still tied in a bun and she still wear Mary Sue's glasses, but her face has returned to its rosy pink hue. She blinks open her eyes, feeling the sunlight, looks out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at the rainbow)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God ... INT. BOWLING ALLEY. The men are all passed out across the various lanes and scoring tables. It looks like a YMCA shelter. After a mom or two Big Bob yawns, and stretches, and glances out the glass doorway. He sees the rainbow and freezes in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (horrified)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my GOD!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David comes gliding up Maple Street in the sunshine with huge smile on his face. He has that special grin and fara look that a boy only knows once in his life. Perplexingly is still in black and white. Bud turns on Elm Street and starts heading for his house when he glances up and sudde freezes. HIS POV. TREE TRUNK. There, tacked to the bark, is a hastily scrawled public notice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks up at it for a moment. INT. PARKER KITCHEN. DUSK. George and Betty stand face to face in their suburban kitchen. He is black and white. She is in full color.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you where I was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got caught in the storm. You were gone all night too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the ultimate defense)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was in a bowling-alley. Betty turns--glances out the window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sudden smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. Let's just forget about it. Let's just go to the meeting and ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, George. I'm not going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bigger smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I'm not. She turns to face him. George flinches slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at me George. That meeting's not for me. Look at my face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine. You'll put on some make up and ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to put on some make up ... George's eyes widen. It's a watershed moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (protesting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It goes away ... It'll go away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want it to go away. He suddenly squares back his shoulders and puffs out his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the '50s patriarch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay--now you listen to me ... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna come to this meeting and you're gonna put on this make up, and you're gonna come home at six o'clock every night and have dinner ready on this table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I'm not sweetie. His expression leaves as quickly as it came. Betty moves closer to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (half whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... There's a meatloaf in the fridge. You just put it in the oven and turn this little knob up to three-fifty. If you put the pie in forty minutes later, it'll be hot in time for dessert. George's eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made a couple of lunches for you and put them in brown paper bags ... (much quieter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna go now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you gonna go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna go now. She turns and starts out the kitchen door when George cal after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty, don't go out there like that! They'll see you! (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll SEE you! And she closes the door behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Betty, come back here! EXT. TOWN HALL. NIGHT. Dozens of black and white citizens stream in through the front door. SHOT. OPPOSITE SIDE OF THE STREET. Several "transformed" teenagers stare at the spectacle wi their FLESH COLORED SKIN AND BRIGHT BLUE EYES. They seem hang back in the shadows. INT. TOWN HALL. Big Bob stands at the podium beneath a permanent banner t reads "PLEASANTVILLE CHAMBER OF COMMERCE." As the only legally constituted body in Pleasantville, it is a natura place for a town meeting. There is nothing bright and che however. The floor lamps in each comer cast huge, looming shadows up the walls. The light at the podium bathes Big Bob's face in a blinding splash of light. The whole thing evokes some weird twisted image from German Expressionism like they are about to go look for Frankenstein. It is gr than gray. CLOSER. PODIUM. Big Bob stands at a lectern with a Rotary insignia on the front. He speaks calmly but compellingly to a hundred men women who hang on his every word. Bob holds a BRIGHT YELL GRAPEFRUIT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was found over in Dave Murphy's trash can. There were four of them like this ... There is a murmur from the crowd ... CLOSE UP. GEORGE. He sits up on the stage in an honored position right behi Bob. George wears a shiny new ROTARY PIN in his lapel, as full-fledged member of the Chamber of Commerce. He sits s and upright with the sense of safety and reassurance that shiny new pin can give you. SHOT. BOB. He holds up a pair of BRIGHT RED BOXER SHORTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jane Davidson found these in her son's laundry basket. There is a LOUDER MURMUR. The crowd shifts in their seats Bob points behind him to a BRIGHT GREEN lawn chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is from Mary Petersen's front porch. She found one last week. There were two more this morning ... The MURMUR starts to grow ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Margaret stand beneath the big Elm tree outside Margaret's house: a statue of two young lovers. They wrap their arms around each other in a classic silhouette. The meeting across town seems a million miles away. After a moment or two, David reaches behind the tree and pulls ou beautifully wrapped gift. It is three feet long with a br RED bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got you something. Margaret's eyes widen. She beams at him, then tears off t wrapping paper revealing a great big umbrella ... a real umbrella. She looks up at him thrilled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful. Where'd you get it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a prop for the school play ... She looks down and giggles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I open it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure ... Margaret gives him a quick kiss then opens the umbrella. puts it back on her shoulder and turns a series of pirouettes--like her own kind of rain dance. Margaret poi her face up to the sky as if she is being showered by a summer storm. All at once a pair of HEADLIGHTS round the corner. WIDER. David grabs the umbrella and closes it quickly. Margaret looks to the street as the convertible slows to a crawl a two TEENAGE BOYS pull up beside them. They are clean cut BLACK AND WHITE faces ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Bud ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clipped)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Whitey. They smile at each other for no good reason. It's scary a arrogant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (more pointed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Margaret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Whitey ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Bud, how come you're not at the town meeting right now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (curt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No reason. (pause/ firing back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you're not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. We're s'posed to go out and let everybody know about it. See. He points to an ARMBAND that has some sort of Chamber of Commerce seal on it. Whitey leans out of the car and leers ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No reason hunh ... See I thought maybe it was cause you were too busy entertaining your colored girlfriend. Margaret literally flinches. The boys share a PEEL OF LAUGHTER AND SNORT AT EACH OTHER. David puts an arm aroun her and pulls her close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you guys just get the hell out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, okay, Bud. We'll do that. He guns the engine as if to leave, then pauses and turns toward Margaret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leering more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know Margaret, you can come over and bake those Oatmeal cookies for me anytime you want to. They share another CHORTLE as Whitey guns the car and pee out with a SCREECH. Margaret's lip starts to quiver and D holds her tighter ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fine ... It doesn't mean anything. She nods, groping for reassurance ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The chamber of commerce meeting is still in full swing. Various citizens are now on their feet, screaming from th audience.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed McFadden's got a blue front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's always been blue!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that blue!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a big tree turning orange in Joe Baker's front yard! SHOT. GEORGE. He still sits behind Bob with the same stoic expression o his face. George fingers the little pin in his lapel ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People, people ... I think we all know what's going on here. SHOT. BOB. Bob lifts his hands in the air. The crowd quiets down a b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obviously certain "changes" have been happening. Up until now, things in Pleasantville have always been-- well ... "Pleasant." And, recently, certain things have become ... "Un-Pleasant." Now it seems to me the first thing we have to do is to separate out the things that are pleasant, from the things that are "Un-Pleasant." There is a loud murmur and nod of agreement ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, why don't you and Burt take the lead on this. Why don't you put together kind of an "Un-Pleasant" Activities Committee ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Johnson has scrubbed the snow scene from the window a stares with his palette at a blank pane of glass. There i knock at the door ... WIDER. Mr. Johnson puts down the paints and crosses to open it. Betty is standing in the doorway clutching her purse and "Lady Samsonite Weekender" bag. She stares up into his ey

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burt Campbell opens up the hardware store like he does ev morning, only today there is a slight difference. He swin open the door, puts out the rakes and shovels, then sets newly handwritten sign clearly in the front window:

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS. SHOP WINDOWS.
dialogues.text: As the businesses are opened on Main Street, more and mor "NO COLOREDS" signs appear in the windows: next to the donuts ... by fishing poles ... beside the stationery supplies ... Everything else looks frighteningly the same

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joey Anderson, the local paper boy, is finishing his morn rounds. He reaches in his bag and tosses left toward the bakery. Then he throws right toward the post office. Then turns left toward the soda shop, does a double take and s into a trash can ... WIDER. SODA SHOP. Where Mr. Johnson had once painted his cubist snow scene, there is a brand new painting that isn't cubist at all. A NUDE version of Betty graces the shop window--painted in curving sensual brush strokes. Joey stops his bike and ju stares in amazement. He gets up and rides away as fast as possibly can ...

dialogues.speaker: MAIN STREET. LATER ...
dialogues.text: David is in a happy daze, wandering up Main Street and doesn't even notice the crowd gathered outside Mr. Johnso soda shop. After a moment or two, he glances up and sees window ... CLOSER. DAVID. His eyes go wide. The murmur of the crowd grows louder as stray derisive comments rise above the noise. David glanc from the nude in window to the growing angry mob ... MAIN STREET. DAY. David goes tearing through the business district looking any sign of his "mother." He glances in the flower shop . toward the green grocer ... David is just about to turn o Elm Street when a booming voice seems to come from the sky ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud ... David stops and looks to his right. There, in the window the Philco TV store, are twenty screens of various sizes displaying the image of Dick Van Dyke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want a word with you ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scared)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh--well ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (BOOMING)

dialogues.speaker: NOW
dialogues.text: The sound reverberates like God Himself. David ducks insi the store, slamming the door behind him. INT. STORE. Fifty Dick Van Dyke's stare at him from every TV in the store. The effect is smothering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (still pretty loud)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell do you think you're doing! David glances around, not sure where to look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (terrified)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I MEAN! (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think this is a toy? You think it's your own little goddamn coloring book ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look--it just sort of "happened" ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A deluge doesn't just "happen." Bolts of lightning don't just "happen" ... (louder)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You burned down an ELM tree for Christ's sake ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had nothing to do with that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. I'm sorry--refresh my memory. What episode does the orgy happen in, again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was a gift Bud. It was so special. You liked these things as much as I did, remember: Warm smells in the family kitchen? A smile from a stranger? You know how rare that is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat/ quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Only if they mean it. Dick Van Dyke looks at him for a beat, then goes "red" in face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (finding courage)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't do anything wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no? Let me show you something! SHOT. TV SCREEN. All at once a box appears in the upper right hand comer o the screen containing the image of David and Margaret at Lover's Lane. The VIDEOTAPE rolls forward as she extends BRIGHT RED APPLE. David hesitates, then takes it, then pu it to his mouth and takes a bite.

dialogues.speaker: "YOU DON'T DESERVE THIS PLACE."
dialogues.text: The image of David biting the apple PLAYS BACKWARDS AND FORWARDS like some football instant replay ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David just stares at the repeated images of Dick Van Dyke the TV screens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the remote control I gave you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you're coming home. I'm gonna put this place back the way it was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No you're not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gathering strength)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry ... I can't let you do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nuts)

dialogues.speaker: JUST GIMME THE GODDAMN REMOTE
dialogues.text: He lunges toward the screen and slams his hand against th "barrier."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (terrified)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to leave now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not going anywhere. You're gonna get that remote and you're gonna come home and we're gonna make everybody HAPPY AGAIN!!! Dick Van Dyke looks at him stunned as David turns and lea the shop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't make me get rough with you! I can get awfully fucking rough! ELM STREET. DAY. David sprints down the tree lined street toward his house The leaves on some of the trees are starting to turn GREE even this far into town. David vaults over Mr. Simpson's hedge and goes tearing up his front walk. INT. FOYER. The door flies open and he rushes in, breathless. David glances around the house to make sure that it is empty. H crosses into the living room. INT. LIVING ROOM. David rushes to the TV and grabs the remote. He looks dow it, glances at the television, then bolts for the front d MAIN STREET. DAY. David moves quickly down Main Street looking for a place stash the remote. He pauses in front of the Pleasantville Travel Agency. It has posters in the window depicting var destinations in and around Pleasantville (the place doesn see much business). David bends down to stash the remote drain pipe near the entrance when he hears VOICES from up street. WIDER. David turns to see a small crowd up near the end of Main Street. He sticks the remote in the drain pipe and rises his feet as the voices get louder. DIFFERENT ANGLE. The crowd is moving toward him. A woman walks in front of group of young men who circle around her, taunting and harassing her. A moment later David can make out the face BETTY clutches her handbag to her chest while the crowd circles her like a pack of dogs. CLOSER. BETTY. The ROSY HUE of her face stands out in stark relief to th black and white faces around her. Betty holds her head hi with dignity (and fear) while the ugly epithets overlap o another "Oooh--let's see the rest of you ... Let's see wh under that nice blue dress ... Bet she's even pinker than picture ..." One of the boys yanks at Betty's skirt and s quickens her pace. Just at that moment the boy is shoved the ground ... WIDER. David shields his "mother" as he shoves one of the boys i the dirt. The kid gets up but David punches him hard in t side of the jaw and the rest of them just stare. (Violenc as new as anything else and it seems to freeze the moment David steps in front of his "mother" with both fists clenched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (as scared as she is)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on! He plants his back foot primed for action. The crowd of b and white thugs just stares at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at him warily. The boy reaches up and feels the side of his mouth where a trickle of RED BLOOD is running down his chin. He looks at his finger in horror and start backing away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out of here! They back away further and David takes a threatening step The boys turn and run as he turns back to face his "mothe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David moves up to her gently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you alright? She nods, still clutching her purse to her chest. David reaches out and touches her cheek when suddenly her eyes wide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (off her look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? CLOSER. STILL OVER DAVID'S SHOULDER. Betty reaches into her purse and pulls out her compact. S opens it, and holds it up to David, showing him the refle image of his own face. AT LAST HE HAS TURNED TO COLOR. REVERSE ANGLE. DAVID. He holds the mirror staring at his own reflection. The courage which transformed him only seems to grow. They lo at each other, both in color now, when David puts a gentl arm around her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on. He begins to lead her up toward the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A larger crowd of hooligans has now gathered around the n painting of Betty in the window. The jeers and cat calls even louder. The "closed" sign still sits in the doorway. After a beat or two, a HUGE BRICK SHATTERS THE GLASS ... WIDER. A big CHEER goes up from the crowd. Drunk on adrenalin, t fever builds and ANOTHER BRICK SMASHES THE WINDOW. In an instant, Mr. Johnson's "canvas" is totally destroyed. The CHEERING grows louder ... Almost by osmosis, the crowd rushes the building together The door is kicked in and they stream into the place. Soo all that can be heard is the weird SOUND OF LAUGHTER AND BROKEN GLASS. INT. SODA SHOP. It is an orgy of destruction. Stools are hurled--tables ripped out. The cash register is turned over. Two boys ki in the front of the juke box ... EXT. MAIN ST. DAY. David and Betty round the corner to find the Soda Shop be destroyed. They stand at the far side of the intersection watching the carnage as the crowd continues to run amok. After a moment or two, there are some more HOOTS as MARGA comes running toward them with the front of her blouse ri open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God. He takes her in his arms and Margaret starts to sob. Davi strokes her hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you alright? Are you okay? She nods. Margaret catches her breath for a moment or two then glances down to her side ... WIDER. She is clutching the umbrella in her left hand. The thing been ripped to shreds. The spines are broken and the fabr is torn. Margaret stares at the thing with a combination confusion and shame. David goes white with rage and looks toward the mob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking his arm)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Let's get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all ride in George's convertible up the twisting tur road. It has turned completely PINK with the dogwood peta David winds up the trail, in the fading light, looking fo refuge. He clutches the wheel tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We should be okay up here. DIFFERENT ANGLE. THROUGH THE WINDSHIELD. The car twists and turns up the narrow dirt road. After a moment, Lover's Lane reveals itself. It is lush and green like before only this time, there is one major difference phalanx of BLACK AND WHITE THUGS have created a roadblock the foreground. WIDER. David jams on his breaks when he sees the barrier. It is weird incongruous image: the black and white roadblock in front with the vibrant colors of the pond and willow behi like some perfect dream you can never get to. The thugs h turned their cars sideways and dragged several huge logs across the road. They hold axe-handles in their hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We better go. EXT. MAIN STREET. NIGHT. Darkness has fallen and the streetlamps have come on. Som debris is scattered around the street and distant sounds the mob still fill the air. David rolls back into town wi the headlights off. CLOSER. CAR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure. They head down Main St. and turn the comer on Walnut. All once, a weird ORANGE LIGHT bathes the car ... REVERSE ANGLE. THEIR POV. A BONFIRE has been lit in the middle of the street betwee library and the barber shop. Twenty to thirty people are gathered around it still whooping and hollering as the br ORANGE FLAMES shoot into the air. ANGLE. CAR. David pulls over by the curb, and their eyes go wide ... REVERSE ANGLE. From closer up, it becomes clear what they're burning. Hu piles of library books have been dumped onto the sidewalk waiting their turn on the pyre. There is a strange celebr atmosphere as they chuck book after book on the flames, w the glee of a teenager tossing a firecracker. David sees something and bolts from the car ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God. ANGLE. SIDE OF THE BONFIRE. Jennifer is locked in some strange wrestling match with B He clutches a book over her head while she tugs at his wr trying to stop him from throwing it on the fire ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't! Just let go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's better, Mary Sue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, NO! (yanking it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I've read like one book in my whole life and I'll be damned if I let you throw it on that fire ... Jennifer wrestles with him for a couple of seconds and th suddenly kicks Biff in the groin. He doubles over in agon when Jennifer snatches the book and bolts in the other direction. DIFFERENT ANGLE. STREET. She sprints up the street and is just passing the barber when a hand reaches out and grabs her. Jennifer starts to scream but David puts a hand to her mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. It's me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd has moved on and all that is left is the dark wreckage of the soda shop. Several stools lie out in the street and shards of brightly painted glass are scattered around the sidewalk. It is eerily quiet. WIDER. David, Betty and Margaret sit silently in the car, across street with the lights off. He unlatches the door handle gets out slowly. The rest of them follow him into the emp street as they move silently toward the soda shop, like s platoon on patrol. REVERSE ANGLE. As they get closer, more of the wreckage comes into view. a booth ... a soda spigot ... After a moment or two Jenni looks up and gasps. CLOSER. Several teenagers step out of the shadows. They have scra faces and ripped clothing--the signs. Most are dazed and OF THEM ARE IN COLOR. After a second or two, more appear: Mary Jane ... Lisa Anne ... The boy who was reading Huck Finn... ANGLE. DAVID. The kids turn to him as if he has some kind of answer. Of course he doesn't. The sounds of the Mob still carry thro the air from somewhere off in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go inside. INT. SODA SHOP. The place is just sad. All the remnants of what they had strewn around the floor, The jukebox is turned over. The stools are ripped out of the floor. Betty looks over at t corner where he painted her ... The easel is smashed to b ANGLE. BETTY. She brings a knuckle to her lip and David puts an arm aro her and draws her close. After a moment or two they HEAR weird SCRAPING sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? The SCRAPING SOUND stops. They all look to the open door after a second or two, Mr. Johnson appears holding a broo dustpan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just thought I'd try to tidy it up a bit. Betty runs across and throws her arms around him. The teenagers watch as she holds him tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. Once we sweep it up it'll be alright again ... Betty stifles a sob as he strokes her hair. No one says anything while they just embrace for a moment. Finally ..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well he's right. Come on. Let's turn these booths back up. "Mary Sue", why don't you help me slide this in front of the door. We'll be okay in here. They respond to the tone of leadership. One by one the ki start to pitch in, sifting their way through the wreckage Jennifer and David slide a barricade in front of the door the kids try to put their shop back together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big Bob stands at the podium addressing a packed house. T atmosphere is odd: somewhere between a bake-off and a lynching. People sit in the aisles and in the window sill Bob points his finger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not the answer people. The crowd quiets a bit. He leans over the lectern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No matter how upset we may get, or how frustrated we may be, we're not gonna solve our problems out in the street. It's just the wrong way to do it. We have to have a "Code of Conduct" we can all agree to live by. His tone grows softer--more concerned ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, I asked George and Burt here to sketch out some ideas-and I think they've done a terrific job. (beat/ scans the crowd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we all agree on these then we can take a vote and I think we'll start to move in the right direction. ANGLE. CROWD. They murmur and nod ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading from the CODE OF CONDUCT")

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "ONE: All public disruption and acts of vandalism are to cease immediately." EXT. BONFIRE. NIGHT. It is still ablaze with books. As Bob continues to READ i VOICE OVER, a firetruck comes screeching up to the curb. SHOT. FIRETRUCK. The same fireman who learned to use the hose before pulls several yards of it from the back of the truck. He can ba contain his excitement as he gets to open the valve and extinguish the raging bonfire ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "TWO: All citizens of Pleasantville are to treat one another in a courteous and "pleasant" manner ..." SERIES OF SHOTS. LAMPPOSTS. The CODE OF CONDUCT is nailed to lampposts and tree trunk rapid succession. It is plastered on walls and in shop windows ... SODA SHOP. Debris is still strewn around the street. A dim light emanates from inside. INT. SODA SHOP. It looks like a scene from the French Revolution. Ten to fifteen kids huddle behind the barricade while David read the code of conduct out loud by flashlight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Courteous and Pleasant manner." That doesn't sound too bad. David just looks at her then continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (reading from THE CODE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "THREE: The area commonly known as Lover's Lane as well as the Pleasantville Public Library shall be closed until further notice." This sends a murmur amongst the kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "FOUR: The only permissible recorded music shall be the following: Pat Boone, Johnny Mathis, Perry Como, Jack Jones, The marches of John Phillips Souza or the Star Spangled Banner. In no event shall any music be tolerated that is not of a temperate or "pleasant" nature."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (overlapping)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Oh my gosh ... No ..." David holds up his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "FIVE: There shall be no public sale of umbrellas or preparation for inclement weather of any kind." Various glances dart back and forth between them. David continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "SIX: No bedframe or mattress may be sold measuring more than 38 inches wide." (pause)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "SEVEN: The only permissible exterior paint colors shall be BLACK, WHITE or GRAY, despite the recent availability of certain alternatives." David looks over at Mr. Johnson who just winces slightly. Betty clutches his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "EIGHT: All elementary and high school curriculums shall teach the "non-changist" view of history-- emphasizing "continuity" over "alteration." (David pauses)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. David lowers the paper. DIFFERENT ANGLE. It is SILENT in the soda shop. Everyone sits motionless f moment or two, letting the decree sink in. David just sta down at the piece of paper in his hand with a weird kind sadness. Off in the corner, however, one of the boys has been fidd with the jukebox and hasn't paid any attention to what wa being read. All of a sudden, his voice rings from the cor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. This thing works. He hits a button and BUDDY HOLLY's voice fills the soda s RAVE ON blares at almost top volume recalling a more fest time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well all the things that you say and do Make me want to be with you-oo-oo ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly/ in a panic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn that off! The boy looks back at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shrieking)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not allowed to do that now! He flinches and pulls the plug from the wall. The jukebox winds down with a groan as the electricity drains out of David looks at the kids then suddenly speaks in a calm cl tone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure you are. He walks across the soda shop and plugs it back in. The k watch spellbound at this personal display of defiance. WIDER SHOT. SODA SHOP. Buddy Holly's voice fills the Soda Shop but it has a sudd different meaning. All the kids listen spellbound, as if an anthem, while the Rock and Roll lives up to its rebell reputation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little things that you say and do Make we want to be with you-oo-oo ... RAVE ON! It's a crazy feeling ... RAVE ON! It's got me reelin' ... Jennifer looks over at her brother with pride. Betty puts arm around Mr. Johnson, feeling a little stronger--a litt safer ... The kids seem to relax a bit, and even if they don't feel totally reassured, at least they don't feel ashamed. Twenty "colored" faces listen as Buddy Holly tells them R ON. David stands beside the jukebox like a captain at the helm of his ship ... EXT. STREET. LATER ... He steps out over the debris and looks both directions. D motions toward the shop and a moment later the kids emerg The disturbance seems to have died down and the street is silent although strewn with debris. David turns to the ki

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stick together till you get off Main Street. They nod and head off down the block. David just watches silently from the wreckage of the soda shop ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Fire Department is cleaning up the charred remains of bonfire ... INT. SODA SHOP. LATER ... Betty is asleep in one of the booths. Jennifer sleeps bes her on the floor. David and Margaret sleep next to them i another booth with Margaret curled up against his chest. David opens his eyes. REVERSE ANGLE. HIS POV. Mr. Johnson is standing in the middle of the shop, starin the large piece of plywood where his window used to be. H just gazes at the thing as if he could look through it. There's a faraway look in his eye. SHOT. DAVID. He rises carefully from the booth, without waking Margare David crosses over to Mr. Johnson and speaks in a whisper

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's okay. We'll get you a new one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what I'd do if I couldn't paint anymore Bud. I just don't know what I'd do ... CLOSE UP. DAVID. He just nods. David glances down at the table next to him picks up one of the brightly painted shards of glass and looks at it. It's orange and pink and yellow. David think for a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe I have an idea.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MAIN STREET. DAWN.
dialogues.text: The same paper boy who rode into the trash can, peddles d Main Street tossing his papers toward the curb. He throws right toward the post office, then left toward the hardwa store, then right toward the bakery, then finally looks u CLOSER. This time the boy slams into a lamp post. He tumbles off bike and stares straight ahead in disbelief ... HIS POV. TOWN HALL. Two men sleep at the base of the wall next to a clutter o paint cans. Above them, however, is painted A VIVID ALMOS UTOPIAN MURAL OF THE TOWN OF PLEASANTVILLE in LIVING COLO Instead of being drab, the place literally gleams with li The post office turns out to be a RICH RED BRICK. The sky shines in vibrant BLUE. It is a rendering of what the tow could look like. David and Mr. Johnson sleep soundly next their own signatures. David opens his eyes and sees the paperboy ... ANGLE. PAPER BOY. He turns around and rides away as fast as he can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A huge crowd has gathered. There is a loud buzz in the ai David and Mr. Johnson stand side by side in front of thei work like they're presenting and guarding it at the same time. REVERSE ANGLE. CROWD. Most of the faces are black and white. A few near the bac are in color. Big Bob moves through the back of the crowd hurriedly buttoning his shirt. The buzz grows and the peo part as he heads toward the front of the pack ... ANGLE. FRONT OF CROWD. When Bob emerges from the crowd, Mr. Johnson flinches slightly. David just looks him in the eye and tries to fi as much courage as he can. "Big" Bob looks up at the colo rendering of his town with absolute horror. His eye scans green trees, the bright yellow gas station, the puffy pin clouds on the horizon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bellowing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you do this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly but clearly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I did. Bob grabs a copy of the Code of Conduct and waves it at h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know that it's illegal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I do. Bob looks dumbfounded. He tries to process the whole thin but just looks more confused. Bob runs his hand through h hair, shaking his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because anybody should be able to paint in whatever color they want. ANGLE. BACK OF CROWD. Betty stands beside Margaret and Jennifer watching the spectacle. There are tears in her eyes and a great deal o love. Jennifer smiles with pride at her brother ... SHOT. BOB.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not allowed to do this! I could arrest you for this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still doesn't make it right. There is some clapping from the back of the crowd. Bob's widen. His face goes flushed (darker gray). A vein bulges his neck. He turns to the police chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dan! Arrest them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um ... I don't know how to do that, Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I never had to do it before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You put handcuffs on them and you take them to the police station.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. guess I could do that, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly stronger)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mere, Dan. I'll help you. David walks toward the police chief and sticks his hands A louder murmur moves through the crowd as David actually helps him fasten on the cuffs. Mr. Johnson comes over to them and the murmur starts to grow ...

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT TIME.
dialogues.text: A bright full moon stands out against a jet black sky ... EXT. MAIN STREET. NIGHT. A group of "colored" kids hangs out on Main Street near t police station. They gaze off into the distance at the ba window of a jail cell. It is elevated half a story above street. Everything is black and white except for the warm YELLOW LIGHT, that glows through the bars. They know in a glance who's inside. INT. JAIL CELL. NIGHT. David sits on his bunk staring at the ceiling. The place never been used so there is still plastic wrapping on all sheets and pillow cases. He can't help smiling. INT. DIFFERENT JAIL CELL. WAY OFF DOWN THE HALL ... Mr. Johnson crouches on his bunk, ignoring his food. He clutches a rusty nail and scratches at the plaster wall i true "inmate" fashion. REVERSE ANGLE. WALL. Rather than scratching the days or even the hours, Mr. Johnson has carved a huge pastoral landscape into the wal complete with lush forest and a running brook. He looks a his work and smiles. SHOT. POLICE CHIEF. He approaches David's cell from the other direction and knocks gently on the bars. David turns around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's someone to see you Bud. DAVID. David sits upright on his bunk trying to think who it cou be. After a moment or two, a strange look of understandin crosses his face. He HEARS the sound of a KEY TURNING IN LOCK. David looks up at the doorway and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it might be you. REVERSE ANGLE. DICK VAN DYKE. He stands in the doorway, still dressed in his TV repairm outfit. FOR THE FIRST TIME, HE IS COMPLETELY IN BLACK AND WHITE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hope you're proud of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am actually ... Glad to see you've finally shown your true colors. Dick Van Dyke gives a tight smile and shuts the door of t cell behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, let's cut the shit and get right to it. Where's that remote control?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you're coming home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you just take me back without it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. You're a smart little bastard aren't you? (tightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's kind of like a restricted ticket. You gotta leave the same way you came. David just looks at him. He smiles, confidently. Leans ba on the bunk ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So ... I guess as long as I'm here, all sorts of things could happen to this place. We could have pink lawns and blue trees ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just gimme the damn remote!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I can't do that. Dick Van Dyke takes a deep breath. He glances toward the barred window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what went wrong. You answered every question. You knew every detail. The senior Prom ... McIntire's Department Store. We had all the same warm memories: Sock hops. The Church Social ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They weren't my memories. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I borrowed them. It's no good when you borrow them. Dick Van Dyke's eyes go wide and he literally starts to tremble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (containing his rage)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long do you think you've been here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (warily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know ... Three, four weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much less than that. (checks his watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An hour and a half. David looks at him uneasily. Dick Van Dyke flashes a broa nasty smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See--and this is really great-- the show was on for what--half an hour a week? So that means for every week that goes by in Pleasantville, only half an hour goes by in the real world. The smile gets bigger. Dick Van Dyke moves closer to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Buddy, you're going on trial tomorrow. And if they find you guilty, you're gonna be stuck here forever. Well, not forever--lemme think ... (calculates)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five year sentence ... Carry the three ... That comes out to ... sixteen and a half centuries, and that's rounding down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going on trial tomorrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is TV pal. They don't fool around. David is rocked but tries not to show it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stoicly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's worse places.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh sure. For the first hundred years. Then it starts to get a little monotonous. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleep well. He taps on the bars for Dan who opens the lock and lets h out. The door CLANGS shut as the two of them disappear do the hall. The minute they are gone, the stoicism falls. D looks around his cell, truly afraid. CLOSER. He stares at the tiny cot ... The plain light bulb in the ceiling ... The single pillow with the plastic covering i ... Forever is starting to look like a long time. David crosses to the small window and looks out. HIS POV. OUT THE WINDOW. Across the town square he can see the side of the Town Ha complete with the newly painted mural. The "Utopian" view Pleasantville is just as he left it with one notable exception: The edges of painting are starting to turn bac BLACK AND WHITE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is bathed in sunlight. Dozens of people stream through front door for the first trial in Pleasantville's history There is a weird carnival atmosphere in the air. INT. TOWN HALL. DAY. The place has been transformed from the Chamber of Commer meeting hall to a small town courtroom, complete with pew and ceiling fans. The only carry over from its previous configuration is the huge CHAMBER OF COMMERCE banner drap across the back wall. ANGLE. BENCH. At the center of the courtroom where the podium used to b a large, elevated judge's bench with a Rotary insignia on front. Big Bob sits six or seven feet above the proceedin finally living up to his name. The whole thing is a stran combination of Franz Kafka and "Inherit the Wind." Big Bo bangs the gavel ... CLOSER. The undertone begins to quiet down. All of the faces in t pews are Black and White. There is a "colored" section in back for standing room only. ANGLE. JURORS BOX. George is seated in the front row of the jury, despite hi relationship to one of the defendants. He is dressed impeccably with his Rotary Pin still gleaming on his lape After a moment or two he sneaks a glance toward the back the room ... ANGLE. BETTY. She stands in the back with the rest of the "colored" fac Betty cranes her head to catch a glimpse of David or Mr. Johnson. All at once, a hush goes through the crowd. ANGLE. DOORWAY. It swings open and David and Mr. Johnson are led in weari handcuffs. Dan, the Police Chief (now ballif), shows them a table in the center of the room directly facing Big Bob There is no lawyer present. There is also no prosecutor. ANGLE. DAVID. He glances around a little confused. (Weird courtroom.) B Bob bangs the gavel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud Parker and William Johnson, you have been charged with desecration of a public building and the intentional use of prohibited paint colors in violation of the Pleasantville Code of Conduct and laws of common decency. Do you admit that on the night of May 1, you did consciously and willfully apply the following FORBIDDEN colors to the Pleasantville Town Hall: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red, Pink, Vermillion, Puce, Chartreuse, Umber, Blue, Aqua, Ox Blood, Green, Peach, Crimson, Yellow, Olive and Magenta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um ... Yes I do. Where's our lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We prefer to keep these proceedings as "pleasant" as possible. I don't think a lawyer will be necessary. There is a murmur and a great deal of nodding amongst the black and white faces. Big Bob smiles to himself then proceeds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you further admit that this was done surreptitiously and under the cover of darkness?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well--it was dark out ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Do you further admit that this unnatural depiction occurred in full public view where it was accessible to, and in plain sight of, minor children?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was accessible to everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well. Let the record show that the defendants have answered in the affirmative to all the charges. He looks directly at them for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have anything to say in your defense? SHOT. DEFENSE TABLE. Mr. Johnson just looks at David, confused and terrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn`t mean to hurt anybody. I just have to paint ... I need to. He gropes for something else to say, but what else is the David glances over and sees him sit slowly back in his se David rises from his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I've got something to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very well ... David looks out over the audience. After a moment or two, looks back at Big Bob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I know why you're doing this. I mean, I understand why you're doing this. I used to feel the same way. I used to want this place to stay just the way it was. I never wanted it to change ... There is a loud MURMUR. Big Bob bangs the gavel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he smiles slightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But nothing stays the same. You get things, and you lose things, and that's the good part and the bad part--but you can't have a good part without a bad part. He turns and sees his mother in the balcony. They lock ey for a moment. David smiles slightly and continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like the basketball team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (leaning forward)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The basketball team?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure. Everybody's upset because they're not winning anymore--but just think how it would feel if all of a sudden they do win. There's a murmur in the gallery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wouldn't it feel better than when they used to win all the time? There is a LOUDER MURMUR. Big Bob looks concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, I know you want it to stay "Pleasant" but there are so many things that are so much better: like Silly ... or Sexy ... or Dangerous ... or Wild ... or Brief ... (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And every one of those things is in you all the time if you just have the guts to look for them. (pointing to the "colored" section)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at those faces back there. They're no different than you are. They just happened to see something inside themselves that you don't want to ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay--that's enough!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I was allowed to defend myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not allowed to lie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not lying ... Here I'll show you. He turns suddenly toward the jury box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Simpson ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What color is that hedge of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Green.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not that hedge. The other one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The one in your mind. The one that you see on a bright cold morning. The one that you see when you walk in front of your house and you just stand there and stare. Mr. Simpson suddenly looks far away. He gets a kind of dr look in his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What color is that hedge? CLOSE UP. MR. SIMPSON.

dialogues.speaker: SUDDENLY AND BEFORE OUR EYES, MR. SIMPSON TURNS TO LIVING
dialogues.text: COLOR. A huge MURMUR moves through the courtroom. Bob ban the gavel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, that's enough!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "No ... Let him finish ... Go on ..." Big Bob lifts the gavel and is about to bang it when Davi suddenly turns toward George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. Dad ... DIFFERENT ANGLE. There is a LOUDER MURMUR. Big Bob just looks at him froze while David confronts his "father." George straightens up

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (solemn)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes Bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you miss her? CLOSE UP. GEORGE. He looks at him stunned. Big Bob bangs the gavel but nobo listens. George just stares at him like he got shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, of course you do, but it isn't just the cooking or the cleaning that you miss--it's something else, isn't it ... George swallows. The UNDERTONE in the room starts to grow he glances toward the back of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (softer whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you can't even describe it. Maybe you only know it when it's gone. Maybe it's like there's a whole piece of you that's missing too. (shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You might even call it "love."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (BANGING the gavel loudly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, that's IT!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (motioning toward the back)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now don't you think she looks just as pretty in color? Don't you think she looks just as pretty as she did the day you met her? Slowly, almost imperceptibly George nods. A single tear r down his cheek. As it traces the side of his face it leav long trail of COLOR behind it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you wish you could tell her that? He nods again and it all comes out. Betty smiles at him through her tears. Even Mr. Johnson smiles as well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (POUNDING the gavel)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why am I out of order?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I don't think it's a circus. And I don't think they do either. David motions behind him to the black and white section. There are now ten to fifteen "colored" faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But see that's just the point. It can't stop at once. Because it's in you. And you can't stop something that's in you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (tightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not in ME.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh sure it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it isn't. He crosses to the bench looking right up at Big Bob. He l over the bench and gets right up in his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smug whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want to do to me right now? Big Bob starts to tremble. He shakes with rage as David m closer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon. Everyone's turning colors. Kids are making out in the street. No one's getting their dinner-- hell, you could have a flood any minute ... Pretty soon you could have the women going off to work while the men stayed home and cooked ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not going to happen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it could happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No it couldn't! Big Bob looks at David and starts to tremble. It starts around the base of his neck, spreads quickly up the rest his head. After a moment or two, Big Bob has gone complet RED IN THE FACE. WIDER. A gasp goes through the courtroom. David looks at him and just smiles. The crowd reaction turns almost to a ROAR as Bob turns and catches his reflection in the window. CLOSE UP. BIG BOB. He sees the ruddy image staring back at him, then looks d at his hands. They have gone completely RED as well. Big freezes for an instant then bolts from the bench in panic flees the room--flinging open the doors to the courtroom. ANGLE. DOORWAY. As Big Bob flees, he reveals an amazing sight: the Town Square GLISTENS IN LIVING COLOR. The huge lawn is a rich green. The sky is a dense opaque blue. Dozens of spectato bolt from their seats and rush to the doorway as the crow moves outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the birds are really chirping. Red Brick, Yellow cars Green hats ... The barber pole in front of Gus' has final turned to red, white and blue--he can't help smiling. Dav walks out into the sunlight and stares in wonder at his creation. The whole town is washed in joy. WIDER. Margaret comes up and throws her arms around him. They me in a rich passionate kiss (in direct defiance of the code conduct). Several people around them actually clap, like spectators at a wedding. Jennifer moves up next to them a looks at her brother making out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uch ... I am like gonna hurl ... David turns and looks at her. Both of them laugh. David throws his arms around his sister as more and more people stream out of the courtroom into the sunlight ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Jennifer stand together on the edge of town. Sh clutches a valise in her hand. He holds the remote contro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you. I'm like positive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This thing works. We could go home right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not ready yet. I gotta do this for a little while. WIDER. They stand on the edge of town (which finally has an edge A large sign says: "Springfield 12 Miles" and for the fir time, the end of Main Street is no longer the beginning. Jennifer is dressed in Mary Sue's clothes with a little b of style thrown in. Rich fields of wheat spread out in th distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides. You think there's like a chance I'm gonna get into college back there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thinks ...)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honestly ... no. They both smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got the admissions letter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're sure about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've done the slut thing, David. It's really kinda old. David nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll come back and check on you in a month. Jennifer nods and gives him a hug. She holds on tight for couple of seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're like the coolest brother in the world. David smiles. Never been called cool before. They suddenl hear the SOUND of a motor and look to their left. A huge Greyhound bus lumbers up the highway, pulling to a halt a the sign. The doors open beckoning her in. Jennifer smile her brother, then turns toward the door ... EXT. MARGARETS HOUSE. DAY. She clutches her umbrella at her side. David holds a bag oatmeal cookies. Each one clings on to the other one's clothing. Their faces are inches apart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna forget about me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No I won't. I swear. Margaret nods. She looks at him for a moment then wraps h arms around his neck. They meet in a long, rich, wet, sof kiss. The umbrella falls to the ground ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like calling you David.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like it too. INT. PARKER LIVING ROOM. David stands in front of the television with Mr. Johnson his side. He holds the remote control in his hand. Mr. Johnson seems pretty amazed at the whole idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well how do you know it won't go back to the way it was?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna keep painting aren't you? Mr. Johnson nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well ... He nods again and thinks about it. They smile at each oth one last time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (remembering something)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (reaching into his pocket)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got something for you. He pulls out a folded piece of paper. Mr. Johnson extends to David who unfolds it and instantly smiles. INSERT. PAPER. It is a small painted replica of their mural in the same vibrant colors. Everything is scaled perfectly, exactly l the one on the wall. SHOT. DAVID.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a little--You know. David looks up at him and smiles. All at once he glances toward the door. WIDER. Betty is standing there holding a brown paper bag. A swea is draped over her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (extending the bag)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made you these for the trip. They're marshmallow rice squares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks. I thought you weren't gonna ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (painful/ quieter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to say goodbye. She looks up at David and their eyes lock. Betty hands hi the bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a meatloaf sandwich in there too. Don't go skipping dinner just 'cause you're not here anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice quivering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And ... wear this on the trip in case it gets cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nodding)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... It's a pretty short trip. She nods as well. Betty puts the sweater around his shoul anyway and fusses with the collar for a second or two. Th she throws her arms around his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so proud of you, Bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks ... I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you too. She clings on tight for a second or two then lets go. Bet flicks away a tear and draws a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well ... She steps back and looks at him. David glances down at th remote.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better stand back a little. Betty and Mr. Johnson cross toward the comer of the room. David points the remote at the TV ...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the ersatz Spanish houses stretch out toward infinity WESTEC security patrol cruises by them at a crawl. A seco or two later, all the sprinklers turn on in uniform synchronization. INT. DAVID'S LIVING ROOM. He stands in the middle of the living room looking at his new/old surroundings. Everything is the same as it was. T black onyx coffee table. The clean burbur rug. The big sc TV in its sleek black cabinet. David looks at it and smil The place is inadvertantly in black and white. CLOSER. He reaches forward and turns on the TV (by hand) flipping around the dial. Jerry Springer is berating a prostitute Tony Robbins hawks self-improvement in an infomercial ... Court TV is doing an O.J. recap. David unfolds Mr. Johnso sketch and glances down at it. He smiles to himself. A different kind of nostalgia ...
